security: Revealing that Abram Chayes was granted security approval for liaison contact with the Covert Action Staff (specifically mentioning NSC 5412/2 matters) discloses sensitive operational relationships and potentially compromises sources and methods. Quoting, "The request for CHAYES' clearance was a 'Blanket' request to permit discussion with him of NSC 5412/2 matters on a need-to-know basis."
summary: This report discusses Abram Chayes' involvement in Lee Harvey Oswald's return to the U.S. from the Soviet Union, along with his security clearance and liaison contacts within the CIA, and also details Samuel VISE's connections to Oswald's case and his past CIA involvement.
summary_one_paragraph: This report, dated January 29, 1964, explores the connections of Abram Chayes, Legal Officer of the State Department, and Samuel VISE, Counsel of the American Embassy in Moscow, to the Lee Harvey Oswald case. It highlights that Chayes was reportedly responsible for Oswald's return to the United States in 1962, detailing his security clearance for discussing sensitive NSC 5412/2 matters and his liaison contact with Archibald Roosevelt, Jr. in C/CI. Additionally, the report notes Samuel VISE's potential involvement with Oswald's case, his past as a contract employee on AB ACTIVE, and his prior consideration for CIA employment, while also touching upon his association with William Orville MUNSELL, who was disapproved for CIA employment due to questionable associations.
title: THE LEE HARVEY OSWALD CASE #351164
